commit.message:
cmd/shfmt: fix typo in shfmt.1.scd

overriden -> overridden

cmd/shfmt: document when --filename is needed for EditorConfig support

EditorConfig files are found based on a script's absolute path,
and the EditorConfig patterns are usually filename-based as well.

When formatting standard input, there is no known filename or path.
Sometimes there's a need to format a stream of bytes in memory
without having to place them on a file, which is why we support stdin.

We added the --filename flag for this purpose a long time ago,
and the tests already verified this fact - we just hadn't documented it.

While here, also add a test case for absolute paths,
and make the man page flags consistently use double dashes.

Fixes #1055.

commit.message:
CI: bump bash image version

We've been testing with Bash 5.2 for some time.
add Go 1.22, drop Go 1.20
CI: bump github actions
bump dependencies before the next release

cmd/shfmt: add --apply-ignore flag for tools and editors

The EditorConfig ignore=true property is currently only obeyed
when walking directories, which is fine for command line users
running shfmt like

    shfmt -l -w .

However, many tools and editor integrations use shfmt via stdin
or by passing a single file argument, and in those cases,
the ignore=true logic does not kick in at all.

There should be a way for a user to force running shfmt on a file,
and that has always been passing a file as a direct argument, like:

    shfmt -w file.sh

We can't break that, but tools do need a way to obey ignore rules.
For that reason, add an --apply-ignore flag which does just that.

Fixes #1037.

cmd/shfmt: support editorconfig language sections

That is, support `[[shell]]` EditorConfig sections when formatting
any shell file, and `[[bash]]` when formatting Bash files.

This is mainly helpful when formatting files with a shebang
but no extension, as then the formatter does use the right language
when parsing and formatting the code, but EditorConfig doesn't kick in
as it only knows how to match by filename per the spec.

This feature is out of the EditorConfig spec,
and upstream is tracking a feature like this at
https://github.com/editorconfig/editorconfig/issues/404 since 2019.
Due to the lack of progress upstream, and how useful this feature
is for shfmt, go ahead and add it ourselves,
with a note that we may change or remove it at any time.

Fixes #664.

verification.payload:
tree b76524b80641f986fa30fd2ef8b0e11152d34c57
parent 3384f3d8e63a56a5fbf2955bb00a4458ea6f68e9
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703801093 +0100
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703801093 +0100

cmd/shfmt: support editorconfig language sections

That is, support `[[shell]]` EditorConfig sections when formatting
any shell file, and `[[bash]]` when formatting Bash files.

This is mainly helpful when formatting files with a shebang
but no extension, as then the formatter does use the right language
when parsing and formatting the code, but EditorConfig doesn't kick in
as it only knows how to match by filename per the spec.

This feature is out of the EditorConfig spec,
and upstream is tracking a feature like this at
https://github.com/editorconfig/editorconfig/issues/404 since 2019.
Due to the lack of progress upstream, and how useful this feature
is for shfmt, go ahead and add it ourselves,
with a note that we may change or remove it at any time.

Fixes #664.

commit.message:
syntax: backquotes affect backslashes in single quotes too

I incorrectly understood that backquote command substitutions
did not affect backslashes in single quotes. For example,

    $ echo `echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\\\./g'`
    1\.2

would be formatted by shfmt as the following, with different output:

    $ echo $(echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\\\./g')
    1\\.2

when in fact we do want to deduplicate the backslashes:

    $ echo $(echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\./g')
    1\.2

Tweak the existing test which expected the wrong result.
Thankfully, we simplify the code now with the fix.

Fixes #1041.

verification.payload:
tree 22e779e5af5d2e9d26349d4232d7cd0d476139fc
parent 28117dbcb766e00aee458eb6346b44b93516df1b
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703587298 +0000
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703587481 +0000

syntax: backquotes affect backslashes in single quotes too

I incorrectly understood that backquote command substitutions
did not affect backslashes in single quotes. For example,

    $ echo `echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\\\./g'`
    1\.2

would be formatted by shfmt as the following, with different output:

    $ echo $(echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\\\./g')
    1\\.2

when in fact we do want to deduplicate the backslashes:

    $ echo $(echo "1.2" | sed -e 's/\./\\./g')
    1\.2

Tweak the existing test which expected the wrong result.
Thankfully, we simplify the code now with the fix.

Fixes #1041.

commit.message:
syntax: better column numbers for escapes inside backquotes

Backslashes inside backquote command substitutions are deduplicated,
so they are not included in any literal values,
but they still need to be counted for the sake of column numbers.

With the input

    last=`echo \\$demo`

we used to think that the literal with Go string value "\\$demo",
deduplicated from the input "\\\\$demo", went from column 12 to 18.
This can't be, since the input literal was seven bytes and not six,
even if we end up parsing the literal as six bytes after deduplicating.
We now correctly parse the column positions as 12 and 19.

Fixes #1028.

verification.payload:
tree 25bdac99d2b08f838993dc65b69cc55471d837d3
parent bcbe8ac4db9074ca4b1012a3e6cb243aa6071f26
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703586470 +0000
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1703586539 +0000

syntax: better column numbers for escapes inside backquotes

Backslashes inside backquote command substitutions are deduplicated,
so they are not included in any literal values,
but they still need to be counted for the sake of column numbers.

With the input

    last=`echo \\$demo`

we used to think that the literal with Go string value "\\$demo",
deduplicated from the input "\\\\$demo", went from column 12 to 18.
This can't be, since the input literal was seven bytes and not six,
even if we end up parsing the literal as six bytes after deduplicating.
We now correctly parse the column positions as 12 and 19.

Fixes #1028.

commit.message:
cmd/shfmt: document how EditorConfig's "ignore" works

In particular, that it only applies when formatting directories.
When directly formatting files, we don't ignore anything.

For #1037.

syntax: detect bash 5.2 rather than 5.1

5.2 was released in late 2022.
We track any changes we might need in our parser via #921,
and aside from that all existing bash tests still pass with 5.2.

syntax: detect bash 5.2 rather than 5.1

5.2 was released in late 2022.
We track any changes we might need in our parser via #921,
and aside from that all existing bash tests still pass with 5.2.

commit.message:
Update Arch Linux package URL in README.md

The old URL returns 404 now.

interp: support subshells with FuncEnviron as Env

FuncEnviron can't support listing all env vars via Environ.Each,
and Runner.Subshell relied on that to make a full copy of an Environ.

Instead of trying to make the full copy upfront, which might not work,
the runner now makes a copy of each variable value in setVar
when it is about to be modified, to prevent subshells from modifying
the values in the parent shell.

This method is still not perfect, hence the added TODOs,
but it's certainly more correct as we fix a significant footgun.

Fixes #1043.

verification.payload:
tree ca19c3a48822a9a76143c5c66170bf389e3b439e
parent bb3e03629081360c7d1251f7c4e33aca9a609f37
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1700083809 +0000
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1700084609 +0000

interp: support subshells with FuncEnviron as Env

FuncEnviron can't support listing all env vars via Environ.Each,
and Runner.Subshell relied on that to make a full copy of an Environ.

Instead of trying to make the full copy upfront, which might not work,
the runner now makes a copy of each variable value in setVar
when it is about to be modified, to prevent subshells from modifying
the values in the parent shell.

This method is still not perfect, hence the added TODOs,
but it's certainly more correct as we fix a significant footgun.

Fixes #1043.

commit.message:
expand: support zero-padding in brace expansions

Per "man bash":

    When either x or y begins with a zero, the shell attempts to force
    all generated terms to contain the same number of digits,
    zero-padding where necessary.

Fixes #1042.

verification.payload:
tree a0054d6bc792cd4629605032f16e73b4da79c755

committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1699995576 +0000

expand: support zero-padding in brace expansions

Per "man bash":

    When either x or y begins with a zero, the shell attempts to force
    all generated terms to contain the same number of digits,
    zero-padding where necessary.

Fixes #1042.

commit.message:
syntax: support brace expansions with uppercase letters

They clearly work in Bash:

    $ echo test{A..C}
    testA testB testC

Updates #1042.

commit.message:
interp: support parentheses in classic test commands

This mimics the logic in the bash test expression parser
in the syntax package, which supported them for years.

Fixes #1036.

interp: support parentheses in classic test commands

This mimics the logic in the bash test expression parser
in the syntax package, which supported them for years.

Fixes #1036.

commit.message:
interp: add TODOs about test operator precedence

Spotted this parser issue when investigating #1036.
Note that parsing of [[ happens in the syntax parser,
but the classic [ test is done in the interpreter.
Both treat both binary operators as having the same precedence.

verification.payload:
tree fb049681517757b82b0dfdc55d0bfd1b58b98584
parent 9477b026ccd2a3b5fa11d8b4aa49ecaf3f3caf84
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1697305930 +0100
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1697307181 +0100

interp: add TODOs about test operator precedence

Spotted this parser issue when investigating #1036.
Note that parsing of [[ happens in the syntax parser,
but the classic [ test is done in the interpreter.
Both treat both binary operators as having the same precedence.

commit.message:
interp,expand: add support for fs.DirEntry

That is, all of our APIs mirroring the signature of ioutil.ReadDir
now gain a "2" sibling with whose signature mirrors os.ReadDir.
The original APIs are deprecated, and where both can be set together,
the new API takes precedence over the old one.

This should lead to minor overhead reductions by default,
as well as for any users of the old APIs who switch to the new ones.
See the godoc explaining why ioutil.ReadDir,
as well as related APIs like filepath.Walk, are deprecated.

verification.payload:
tree f686506c8768540b218575808b7214384fa5a352
parent 1813ddeb260695c4fa176d2851590555dc8ca877
author Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1696712289 +0100
committer Daniel Martí <mvdan@mvdan.cc> 1696712296 +0100

interp,expand: add support for fs.DirEntry

That is, all of our APIs mirroring the signature of ioutil.ReadDir
now gain a "2" sibling with whose signature mirrors os.ReadDir.
The original APIs are deprecated, and where both can be set together,
the new API takes precedence over the old one.

This should lead to minor overhead reductions by default,
as well as for any users of the old APIs who switch to the new ones.
See the godoc explaining why ioutil.ReadDir,
as well as related APIs like filepath.Walk, are deprecated.

commit.message:
interp: determine access to a directory via unix.Access

Rip out the body of interp.hasPermissionToDir and replace it with just a
call to unix.Access(path, unix.X_OK).

Update the function signature of hasPermissionToDir in os_notunix.go,
too.

Fixes #1033.
